journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Impact evaluation of Kevlar-based angle-interlock woven textile composite structures

article-meta.aff: 1Textile Engineering Department, NED University of Engineering and Technology, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan
2The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: Bilal Zahid, Textile Engineering Department, NED University of Engineering and Technology, Karachi 75270, Sindh, Pakistan. Email: drbilalzahid@neduet.edu.pk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article is a part of the research investigating the impact evaluation of angle-interlock woven Kevlar-based composite structures. The research work focuses on energy absorption and force attenuation. This study was conducted in order to understand the behaviour of the fabric layering effect on composite properties and the effect of layering orientation in multilayer composites. In this article, Kevlar-based textile composite structures having angle-interlock weave were developed using vacuum bagging technique and impact tests were carried out on the drop weight impact testing instrument. The result shows that the thickness plays a vital role in energy absorption and force transmission capabilities.

sec.title: Research background
sec.p: The matrix phase (resin) and the reinforcement phase (fabric) are the building blocks for a composite material. In this study, angle-interlock (AI) fabric has been used as the reinforcement phase and thermoset epoxy resin was used as the matrix phase. The physical and mechanical properties of the developed composite structures from five-layer AI fabric has been calculated and analysed.1 Special five-layer AI fabric was made and single piece textile reinforced helmet shells were successfully developed using modified vacuum bagging.2 Fabric layering and layering orientation are significant factors that can impact the performance of the composite panels. For this reason, in this study, the fabric layering effect and the layering orientation are studied based on force attenuation and energy absorption.

sec.title: Manufacturing of AI fabric
sec.p:
AI fabric is one of the three-dimensional fabrics; it usually consists of interlocking binder warp yarns, straight aligned weft yarns and optional wadding warp yarns,3 as shown in Figure 1.4 Due to its good inherent mouldable properties, AI fabrics are used in making helmet shells.2,5 Figure 1.
Cross-section of ‘through-the-thickness’ angle-interlock fabric.

In this study, ‘through the thickness’ AI fabric has been used and manufactured on conventional shuttle loom – ‘Arbon 100 W’ made by Adolf Saurer™. Kevlar® (Aramid) roving type 49 supplied by DuPont™ is used in both warp and weft yarns. The manufactured fabric has a construction of 5-8-28 AI weave, i.e. 5 layers of weft yarns, 8 ends/cm and 28 picks/cm. The properties of the Kevlar are listed in Table 1.6 Table 1.
Properties of Kevlar®-49 in comparison with Kevlar®-29.
Property Kevlar 29 Kevlar 49
Density (g/cm3) 1.44 1.44
Tensile modulus (GPa) 70.50 112.40
Ultimate tensile strength (MPa) 2920 3000

sec.title: Manufacturing of 5-8-28 Kevlar-based AI-composites panel
sec.p: Vacuum bagging is a clamping method in which atmospheric pressure was used to hold the matrix and reinforcement in place until the resin cures. For conception, vacuum bagging is a technique in which the textile or preform is covered with peel-ply, releasing film, breather fabric and vacuum bag film.7–12

Huntsman epoxy resin Araldite® LY 5052 was selected as the matrix in this study due to its easy accessibility and also because it is common practice in the industry. Araldite® LY 5052 was mixed with hardener Aradur® 5052 in the ratio of 100:38 by weight or 100:47 by volume.13 In order to obtain optimal properties of the matrix, weighing and mixing were carried out precisely. According to the manufacturer,13 curing was carried out in two stages: the laminates were initially cured at room temperature for 24 h and then these laminates were taken off the mould or vacuum bags and were further cured at 100℃ for 4 h. Araldite® LY 5052/Aradur® 5052 matrix has low viscosity due to which it can be simply applied to the reinforcing material. This will make it easy to penetrate the AI fabric. This matrix has a long pot-life (2 h for 100 ml); this means it has sufficient processing time that allows production of big objects. This property helped in the complete impregnation of the fabric. The matrix is a transparent liquid so there is no colouring effect; moreover, this matrix has high temperature resistance, making it a good choice for composite manufacturing.

Three types of AI-composite panels were manufactured from the Kevlar-based, 5-8-28 woven AI fabrics: a one-layer composite, a two-layer composite and a three-layer composite. The two-layer and three-layer composites were further sub-divided in two categories according to the stacking orientation of the Kevlar fabric layers while manufacturing the composite. The different varieties of the developed composite structures are shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Developed varieties of angle-interlock composite panels.

In the 0/0 orientation two-layer AI-composite panel, two pieces of AI fabric were stacked together in such a way that the warp of the second piece of AI fabric was in the same direction as the warp of the first piece of AI fabric. However, in the 0/90 orientation, the warp of the second piece of AI fabric was in a direction parallel to the weft of the first piece of AI fabric. A similar stacking procedure was repeated for the 0/0/0 and 0/90/0 categories of three-layer composites, in which three AI fabric layers were stacked to produce composites panels. After vacuum bagging, the composite specimens developed were further cut into pieces for impact testing using the University of Manchester’s water-jet diamond cutter (see Figure 3). Figure 3.
Flat angle-interlock composite panels for impact testing.

sec.title: Experimental results of AI-composite panel
sec.p: Low energy impact testing on composite structures can be carried out in number of ways, as discussed by Abrate,14 but the major three categories are: gas gun, drop weight and pendulum. In this research, the modified in-house University of Manchester’s Dynatup 8200 drop weight impact testing instrument was used and impact testing was carried out.

In the drop weight system, the potential energy of the system is converted into kinetic energy during an impact on the specimen. Friction in the mechanism is supposed to be zero due to the free fall motion of the impactor. The impact force (contact force or load) follows Newton’s second law of motion, which is expressed as follows
(1)Fi⊗=m a where, m is the mass of the impactor assembly and a is the measured deceleration of the impactor assembly during the impact process. Energy absorption can be calculated by integrating the closed area of the load deflection curve.15 Graphically, the area beneath the load–displacement curve gives the absorbed energy. The University of Manchester’s drop weight impact testing instrument is capable of detecting the force transmitted Ft and the impact force Fi. Force-blocking effectiveness, which is expressed as the attenuation factor, fatt, for each impact can be calculated using equation (2)
(2)fatt=(1-FtF)100 where Ft is the transmitted force collected and F is the impact force acting directly on the anvil without any specimen.

Force attenuation has been studied by many authors.15–18 A higher value of attenuation factor corresponds to less force being transmitted through the specimen and a lower value of attenuation factor indicates that much of the impact force has been transmitted through the specimen (100% means no force transmitted and 0% means all forces transmitted).

The basic idea was to calculate the impact energy absorbed by the composite laminates and the force attenuation factor. A mass of 4.66 kg was dropped on to the developed AI-composite panels with three different impact energies: 5.6, 15.6 and 25.6 J, respectively.

As discussed above, the AI-composite panels were manufactured in such a way that the effect of laminate thickness due to fabric layering and fabric orientation can be studied based on energy absorption and force attenuation. The thicknesses of the laminates were measured and are shown in Table 2. Table 2.
Average thickness of the manufactured angle-interlock composite panels.
One-layer composite Two-layer composite Two-layer composite Three-layer composite Three-layer composite
0/90 Orientation 0/0 Orientation 0/90/0 Orientation 0/0/0 Orientation
mm mm mm mm mm
0.962 1.887 1.905 2.778 2.735

sec.title: Effect of laminate stacking and orientation on energy absorption
sec.p:
Six specimens from each of the five categories of AI-composite panels were impacted with different impact energies. The absorbed energies have been converted to normalised energy absorbed with respect to the average thickness of the specimens. The average results have been tabulated in Table 3. Table 3.
Tests results for the energy absorption performance with three different impact energies.
Sample Impact energy (J) Energy absorbed (J) Normalised energy absorbed (J)
K E EN
FS 5.59 3.825 3.978
FDS 5.56 4.020 2.110
FDD 5.53 4.037 2.140
FTS 5.58 4.026 1.472
FTD 5.63 4.162 1.498
FS 15.62 9.961 10.358
FDS 15.58 9.946 5.221
FDD 15.53 9.946 5.272
FTS 15.51 9.976 3.648
FTD 15.47 9.953 3.582
FS 25.61 16.597 17.258
FDS 25.61 17.016 8.933
FDD 25.59 16.771 8.889
FTS 25.52 16.705 6.108
FTD 25.41 17.839 6.421

In Table 3, FS is the term for the average result of single-layer or one-layer flat AI-composite panels, FDS is the term for the average result of double-layer or two-layer flat AI-composite panels with the same orientation (0/0), FDD is the term for the average result of two-layer flat AI-composite panels with different orientation (0/90), FTS is the term for the average result of triple-layer or three-layer flat AI-composite panels with the same orientation (0/0/0), FTD is the term for the average result of three-layer flat AI-composite panels with different orientation (0/90/0), K is the impact energy just before the impact and is extracted from the velocity detector at the time of impact, E is the absorbed energy and is calculated using the trapezoidal method, EN is the normalised energy absorbed and is obtained by dividing the absorbed energy of the laminates by the thickness of the respective laminates.

Figure 4 shows that the energy absorption is directly proportional to the impact energy. Furthermore, from Figure 5–7 it can be observed that the layering has a significant effect on the normalised energy absorption values. The composite panels having one fabric layer absorb the most energy compared with specimens having multiple layering. However, there is no significant difference observed in the energy absorption due to different orientations. The amount of material seems to be one of the important factors to be considered while designing AI-composite panels. The more the thickness, the less will be the energy absorption by the laminates with respect to amount to material present in the laminates. Furthermore, the one-layer composite panel seems to be more flexible due to less thickness than the multi-layer composite panels. This seems to be one of the reasons why the one-layer composite absorbs more energy. Figure 4.
Energy absorption of angle-interlock composite panels.
Figure 5.
Energy absorption of flat angle-interlock composite panels for 5.6 J impact.
Figure 6.
Energy absorption of flat angle-interlock composite panels for 15.6 J impact.
Figure 7.
Energy absorption of flat angle-interlock composite panels for 25.6 J impact.

sec.title: Effect of laminate stacking and orientation on force attenuated factor
sec.p:
During an impact, the force detected beneath the specimen by the force sensors is known as the transmitted force. It can be seen from Figure 8 that the peak transmitted force increases with the increase in impact energy. The single-layer composite always transmits a higher force compared with the four other thicker categories. Normalised transmitted force (FNtrans) for each laminate type is obtained by dividing the transmitted force of the laminates by the thickness of the respective laminate. Figure 8.
Force transmitted (normalised) for angle-interlock composites panels.

In Figure 9–11, orientation has caused no significant trend, as shown in the two-layer and three-layer composite panels, irrespective of the impact energy. However, the higher the number of layers in a composite, the smaller is the transmitted force. It must be noted that there is a significant difference between the one-layer composite and the two-layer composite results, compared with the two-layer and three-layer composite transmission impact testing results. This may be due to the fact that a one-layer composite is more flexible and unable to resist, compared with the multi-layer composites. Figure 9.
Peak transmitted force of flat angle-interlock composite panels for 5.6 J impact.
Figure 10.
Peak transmitted force of flat angle-interlock composite panels for 15.6 J impact.
Figure 11.
Peak transmitted force of flat angle-interlock composite panels for 25.6 J impact.

Table 4 shows the average force attenuation factor for all the five categories of AI-composite panel for different impact energy levels. The normalised attenuation factor (fNatt) is obtained by using the normalised force transmitted in the calculations. The normalised force transmitted is obtained by dividing the force collected by the force sensor divided by the average thickness of the specimens. Table 4.
Experimental results for the force attenuation factor.
Sample Impact energy (J) Impact force without specimen (kN) Force transmitted (kN) Normalised force transmitted (kN) Normalised attenuation factor (%)
K F Ftrans FNtrans fNatt
FS 5.59 9.242 8.253 8.737 5.466
FDS 5.56 9.242 7.643 4.080 55.857
FDD 5.53 9.242 7.613 4.103 55.600
FTS 5.58 9.242 7.643 2.842 69.253
FTD 5.63 9.242 7.584 2.776 69.967
FS 15.62 15.513 14.311 14.813 4.510
FDS 15.58 15.513 13.721 7.170 53.784
FDD 15.53 15.513 13.692 7.224 53.435
FTS 15.51 15.513 13.544 4.929 68.224
FTD 15.47 15.513 13.397 4.800 69.061
FS 25.61 19.666 18.649 19.214 2.300
FDS 25.61 19.666 18.088 9.379 52.311
FDD 25.59 19.666 18.000 9.423 52.083
FTS 25.52 19.666 18.038 6.522 66.837
FTD 25.41 19.666 18.029 6.410 67.408

For every type of AI-composite developed, the percent force attenuated factor decreases with the increase in impact energy, as shown in Figure 12, which seems to be due to more force being transmitted in the higher energy impacts. From Figure 13–15, it can be seen that the force attenuation factor of single-layer composites is always less than that for the multi-layer composites, irrespective of the impact energy. Three-layer composites, due to large amount of material, block more impact force, compared with the two-layer composites. Orientation in the samples showed no major trends in the two-layer and three-layer composite specimens with respect of the attenuation factor. Figure 12.
Force attenuation factor for angle-interlock composites panels.
Figure 13.
Force attenuation factor of angle-interlock composite panels for 5.6 J impact.
Figure 14.
Force attenuation factor of angle-interlock composite panels for 15.6 J impact.
Figure 15.
Force attenuation factor of angle-interlock composite panels for 25.6 J impact.

One of the important findings is that the percent force attenuation factor remains in very close range for the 5.6, 15.6 and 25.6 impacts. For one-layer composites, it is between 2.30% and 5.47%, for two-layer composites it is between 52.08% and 55.86% and for three-layer composites, it is between 66.84% and 69.97%. This means that by increasing the number of AI fabric layers in composite manufacturing, a significant amount of force can be attenuated.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The AI-composite panels were manufactured in order to understand the behaviour of the fabric layering effect on the composite properties and the effect of layering orientation in the multilayer composites.

The experiments were conducted in a particular range of impact energies—from 5.6 to 25.6 J—and it can be seen that in this particular range of low-energy impacts, the one-fabric-layer composite shows different behaviour, compared with the multi-layer counter ones. The one-layer composite being more flexible in nature, compared with the two-layer and the three-layer composites, absorbs more impact energy and more force transmits, compared with the two-layer and three-layer composite panels. It can be seen that the orientation of the fabric in the composites is not an influential factor for 5.6–15.6 J of impact. Furthermore, the single-layer AI-composite panel exhibits lower force attenuation factor when compared with multi-layer AI-composite panels. It can be observed that the increase of a single layer in the composite structure can increase the force blocking performance.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was financially supported by NED University of Engineering and Technology, Karachi, Pakistan.
